captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

MIKE MUSTO: My name
is Mike Musto.

Each week I travel the country
with the goal of showcasing

the best and baddest muscle
cars and hot rods around.

Every car has a past and
every owner a story.

Welcome to the world
of /BIG MUSCLE.
[CAR ENGINES]

MIKE MUSTO: So today is actually
kind of a really cool

day for us here on
/BIG MUSCLE.

We're actually behind the wheel
of a car that really

kind of epitomizes what the '60s
muscle car was all about.

This is a 1967 Ford
Mustang Fastback--

pretty much the same car that
you saw on the movie

"Bullitt," although I think
that was the '68--
except this car is a drag car.

The car belongs to a gentleman
named Greg Smith.

And when we first saw the car,
it was one of those things
that kind of jumped out at us.

I mean, it's not a
canyon carver.

It's not something that you
would say is a real super
high-end performance machine.

You don't go out on the freeway
with this thing.

It was built to go down the
1320 as fast as it can.

You look around at certain
things on this car you're
going to notice stuff.

And from the point of view of
the car itself, it's just all
functionality.
There's really no fluff here.

For instance, you look at the
Fenton wheels that are on this

car, right-- the Fenton
slotted wheels.

You've got these wonderful 3
and 1/2 inch wide 15 inch
slots in the front.

And you've got 15 by, I think
they're 10 and 1/2s in the

back, with drag slicks
on them.
And what does that do?

Well it's just made to make
the car hook up and go.
The car runs--

no front sway bar-- so when
you go into a corner like

this, you're kind of like OK,
well I've got to take it a

little easy because the front
width of the tires that you're
on is basically like this.
It's like a motorcycle tire.
It's really, really nice.

It's an enjoyable
car to drive.

But when you think of the fact
that this thing has a massive

Currie nine inch rear
in it with 4:10
gears, it's really stout.

It's made to take
a lot of power.
And that power is here.

So for instance, we're
in third gear, but if
we roll onto it--
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

I mean, just from that,
you can feel this
thing get up and go.

It's a really kind of
exhilarating thing to drive.

But where we drove that 1929
Nostalgia Dragster a while

ago, where that one was
frightening to drive, this one

is just kind of a normal car
with that Jekyll and Hyde
personality, right?

So you can take it, you can go
to the diner with it, you can
bring your wife out in it.

People understand what it is
when they see you pull up.

All right, that car's meant to
go fast in a straight line.

But it's docile enough
that you can do it.

Or you can take it out and
you just like I said--
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]
--roll into it.
And I mean the thing--
it just hooks and goes.

Now, as with any drag
car, when you get on
the power it's great.

You just hold on for the ride
and you go straight and
everything is hunky dory.

But when you let off, it's
kind of like bingo.

An overweight person or an NFL
linebacker coming at you with
full speed.

You want to get out
of the way.

But then when they stop--
it's a train wreck,
so there you go.
That's what a drag car is.

-You just compared the drag car
to a fat person running.

MIKE MUSTO: I did compare
a drag car to
a fat person running.
And that's OK.

I apologize out there if you
people don't agree with me,
but that is my comparison.

Fast, fat people equal
drag cars.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

MIKE MUSTO: You know so many
guys get a car like this and

they change everything
immediately to personalize it.

And be like, I can make it
bigger and better and badder
and whatever the case is.

But I mean looks wise the only
thing you did was change the

hood scoop and you added
the cage, correct?
GREG SMITH: Yeah.

I had to put the roll bar in
to be legal at the track.
For the looks, that's it.
I put a new carpet in.
It had a huge hole.

It had a vertical gate shifter,
and the hole was

probably this big in the
floor-- this long.
So I patched that up--

we had an automatic
so we put that in.

I mean, the way I look at I'm
kind of like the caretaker.

That's the way I look
at this car.
I don't want to change it.
I don't want to paint it.

I don't want to put different
rims on it.
I like it the way it is.
MIKE MUSTO: OK.

Well what do you have
under the hood?

GREG SMITH: It's
a 393 Windsor--
stroker Windsor.

MIKE MUSTO: And what's
the quickest you've
run this on the strip?
GREG SMITH: On motor--

11:40, and with a 150
shot of nitrous--

MIKE MUSTO: I was
going to say--

I was like, wow nitrous
made that much of
a difference, huh?
Yeah, that's worth it.

GREG SMITH: That's a
whole lot of 10.
Yeah, no.
I'm sorry-- it was a 10:28.

MIKE MUSTO: Gee that's
fast, man.

GREG SMITH: Yeah, it
cooks pretty good.

MIKE MUSTO: You know
it's interesting.

Like the shifter in this car
is a B & M ratchet shifter.
It's a 3-speed.
It's a reverse valve body.

So basically what you're doing
is you've got your first gear,

pull the thing and pull
it back and the
car jerks into first.

I mean you know the
car is in gear.

But then once you're on
it you just kind of
row through the gears.

I mean we're in first, I mean,
but like I said then if you
row into it--
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MIKE MUSTO: He also has a
massive nitrous tank in the

back-- with like a 150 shot--
and that's what this little
red button's for.

But we're not pushing that
because we're not going to
blow anything up.
It's not our car and I just--
I don't know.

Nitrous is not my thing to
be honest with you guys.

So what other things do we
notice about the car itself if
we talk about the interior?
It's actually quite stock.

Dashboard is stock, radio,
the bezels, the gauges.
They're all stock.

I mean we have a fuel pressure
gauge on the hood which we can
obviously see.

And then we've got the general
gauges, right?

We've got water temp, we've got
our bulb gauge, and we've
got our oil pressure gauge.

One of the other things we have
is Greg's got this sun
tach right on the dash.

That's really kind of a nice
nostalgic old school piece.

He actually had the tach rebuilt
with VDO internal, so

it's accurate and
it works good.

But otherwise the interior's
pretty well stock.

I mean granted, there is a
really big roll cage in here.
And it's an eight point cage.
But that's safety reasons.

You're going to drag race a car
that runs 10:90s, I got
news for you.
You better have a cage in it.
[CAR ENGINE]

MIKE MUSTO: Obviously, you've
got the '67 Mustang and you've

got another '67, and then
you also have the '55.

Would you ever entertain making
one of those into like

a crazy, full-on gas or blower
sticking out of the hood,

solid live action
on the front?

GREG SMITH: I've seriously
thought about that.
I wanted to do it.

But I-- since it was my
grandmother's car-- it's the

one thing I don't think I
could hack off the front
suspension.
MIKE MUSTO: Right.

GREG SMITH: You know, with
the [INAUDIBLE].
I mean, I'd love that.

I'd have to find another
'55 to do it to.
MIKE MUSTO: Right.

GREG SMITH: I mean that car's
been changed so much.

At this point, it probably
wouldn't really matter.

But that's the one thing that's
left that I'm holding
on to, kind of, you know.
Like the original car.

MIKE MUSTO: Well you have
a son too, don't you?
GREG SMITH: Yeah.
MIKE MUSTO: And how old's he?

GREG SMITH: Yeah, he'll be
seven in like a month.

MIKE MUSTO: So is this car going
to him, or is the '55
going to him?
GREG SMITH: Yeah, either one.

Or worst case scenario, sell
the car-- college fund.
I'm willing to do that.

But I'm not going to
sell them all.

I'll only sell one
or two of them.
[CAR ENGINE]

MIKE MUSTO: When we first saw
this car one of the first
things we noticed--
the hood scoop, right?

You could tell there's been
something there before.

I mean there's this hood
scoop on there now.

But the old cal I think
was from a Boss 302
used to be on there.

And the rivets on the hood are
still reminiscent of that.

Greg never bothered to fill
them in because he's like,
well screw it.

He's like, that's part of
the history of the car.

And it's really kind of nice
that he left them there.

You gotta go back to what
your definition of
perfect car is, right?
To us, this car is amazing.
It's fantastic.

You can actually see
the history, right?

On the driver's side door for
instance, there used to be a

sticker there that
said driver.
And that sticker is long gone.

But if you look under the paint
at the right angle you

can actually make out the D and
the R and the I of where
it said that.

There were also fade marks in
the paint from where the old
school stickers used to be.

Which subsequently were
taken off the car and
put under the hood.

It was kind of a really
cool, cool way to pay
homage to this thing.
Is it a high-gloss show car?
It's not even close to that.
But it was never meant to be.

It was meant to be a
flat out dragster.
[CAR ENGINE]

MIKE MUSTO: Well I was saying a
lot of cars have squeaks and
rattles into them.
And this car does.
And you hear it, right?

But, I mean, what do you
really want to hear?

Well you probably want
to hear this.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MIKE MUSTO: God, this
is so much fun.

I'm going to tell everybody
this right now, OK?

I don't know what you guys who
are watching do for a living,

where on the planet that
you live or work, who
your friends are.
But I'm telling you--

if you ever get the opportunity
to jump behind the

wheel of a small block or a big
block muscle car, and you

get to row through the gears
and experience it--
do it.
Don't say no.

You get in these cars and
there's no electronics, and

there's no nav, and no anything,
or OBD ports where

people can track you and be
like, ah you were speeding--

we're going to void
your warranty.

These cars are just
meant to drive.
They're meant to go out.

They're meant to row
through the gears.

They're meant to speed and do
burnouts, and do donuts and
break rules with.

Like I said, you guys get
the opportunity--
don't pass it up.
Just say yes and do it.
Please, I'm telling you.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]
MIKE MUSTO: So, guys, listen.

As always, thanks
for watching.

And if you've got a car that
you're interested in seeing on

/BIG MUSCLE, obviously email us
at DRIVEBIGMUSCLE@GMAIL.COM

and if we can dig it and we can
shoot it, then we will.

But otherwise, stay tuned
for next week.

Greg, thanks so much for letting
us shoot this thing.
GREG SMITH: No problem.
MIKE MUSTO: Absolute blast.
The car was outstanding.
And that's it guys.
See you later.

So ladies and gentlemen, right
now we're going up to the

Sherwood Country Club because
we just need a
place to turn around.

We're in Southern California in
one of the most hoity-toity

spots that you're ever
going to see.

I kind of want to
go to the valet.
Can we use the valet?

Oh, we're coming up
to the window.
This is going to be awesome.
Let's see what he says.
Hey, bud.
We just want to turn around.
Can we do that?

Can we do a big smokey
burnout, like all
the way up and down?

Can we do like a big smokey
burnout in the country club?
We're not allowed to do that?
Are you sure?
All right.
It'd be really cool, though.
Thanks.
He said no.
He said no.
Jerk.

comments.text: my favorite big muscle yet﻿
comments.author: toms5oh

comments.text:
A college degree is very important. My wife and I worked very hard to put 
four sons through college. Two of my sons have several muscle cars because 
of their high paying jobs. I am 66 and have restored and sold many muscle 
cars. I was just trying to be funny.﻿

comments.text: My dream muscle car . One day I will own a fastback﻿
comments.author: Armando  Gonzalez

comments.text:
Y'know, like does this guy like ever not giggle like a schoolgirl, y'know, 
when he get's like hooked to some power? How people are comfortable letting 
this guy drive their cars hard, all the while talking nonstop is beyond me. 
Great cars, good footage and interviews, but daaaamn.﻿
comments.author: Nunya Binniss

comments.text:
an overweight person and an NFL linebacker coming at you at full speed are 
two completely different things... nice car tho.lol﻿
comments.author: Rene Rodriguez

Wow...I JUST learned what 1320 was when you said it. All of my life, I had 
no idea, even after subscribing to the 1320 video. SMH.﻿
comments.author: focused313

comments.text:
I couldn't imagine how tight of a fit that would be fully caged.  Slick

comments.author: MrBigChives

comments.text:
I used to have one of them. 1967 GTA. Hypo 390, 715 Holley, 325 locker, 
smog exempt. It was even the same golden green metallic. My father drove it 
for one mile and got into a quite innocent accident. But it was totaled. 
--And yes, it hauled ass!!﻿
comments.author: davess357

comments.text:
if someone could plz answer this post i would greatly appreciate it im 
planing on getting a 74 dodge charger stock it has 150-170 with the 318 
stock i want to put in a new gear set would 4.10 be way too much for 
highway? i would imagine so but if a few experienced car enthusiests out 
there think it could survive i would put it in﻿
comments.author: mike wills

comments.text:
3:23 would be a versatile ratio. I've had cars with mid 3's ratios. The 3:55 
was great for surface streets, not so much for the freeway. The 3:25 was 
totally reasonable at all speeds and provided significantly more quickness 
than a 3:00 would have.
comments.author: davess357

comments.text:
Get a 3:23 rear gear for your car for good highway/speed performance.  Keep 
your 318 and build it, tons of companies sell performance parts for those 
engines.  Lastly, get an aftermarket 5 or 6 speed tranny.
comments.author: Chris Pappas

comments.text:
One word answer... NO. It would
 not be reasonable.
comments.author: davess357

comments.text:
Use your tire size and transmission ratios to calculate engine RPM at 
cruising speed. This will tell you if it's reasonable. The Grimmjeeper 
website has a good calculator.

Join an online forum for old Chargers dude! Forums rock.
comments.author: four27060

comments.text: I want that car! Now!﻿
comments.author: Hugo Galindo Correa

comments.text:
My dad's friend had a '67 convertible when I was growing up, so I have 
always loved these cars. Thanks for an awesome video! :)﻿
comments.author: Pat Eldridge

comments.text:
funny you ask, i just got the opportunity to drive an 75 trans Am and i

comments.author: ShowCare {Reviews}

comments.text: Why do Americans like automatics so much?﻿
comments.author: AGH0STBUSTER5

comments.text:
+1redrubberball You don't need to make excuses for them. They are all the 
same, making snide remarks about US citizens on countless YouTube videos 
and elsewhere, *their jealousy showing through clearly.* I suppose it's 
part of the modern world in general, where fewer care how they come off or 
how they appear. Intelligent discourse is no longer expected or even 
considered desirable.
comments.author: Maindrian Pace

comments.text:
+Maindrian Pace
I don't know. Perhaps because of the same reasons we American's have 
preconceived notions about foreigners!
comments.author: 1redrubberball

comments.text:
+1redrubberball
Why do foreigners from unspecified countries have so many silly 
preconceived notions about Americans?
comments.author: Maindrian Pace

comments.text:
+JohnnyWhiplash1
I knew I had a missing brother out there.
comments.author: Nunya Binniss

comments.text:
For practicality I guess. I personally like standard better that what I 
learned on my grandpa's tractor
comments.author: Tony Armstrong

comments.text:
Cuz this is a damn drag car and makes sense. And why the hell does it 
matter? But as he said it has a reverse valvebody so he still has to shift 
it just no clutch. Autos are faster and more consistent which is why this 
one has one. And before people start bitching at me like I can't drive, I 
daily drive a 14 mustang gt with a manual. I love my car and it's fun and I 
do race it. I have friends who drove manuals all their life but when they 
got serious about racing they either did a trans swap or bought a new car 
with an auto.
comments.author: Auto Young

comments.text:
well i wasn't meaning it bad.the  reason i said it was because like my 
grandfather he has a bad back and his legs go numb on him because of the 
clutch ,and my grandmother has had a stroke and it very hard for her to 
drive one .so for people like that is when an automatic is good . and sorry 
if you thought i was meaning it bad sir.
comments.author: Nick Moore

comments.text:
+Nick Moore some of the best manual drivers I know are older and I learned 
from my dad how to drive manual who is also somewhat older.
comments.author: BCH37501

comments.text:
+Nick Moore
Nick, that's not a good outlook on your part. I also live in NC, I'm 67 and 
still like manual transmissions but not all folks do, even most young 
folks. Lot's of people have difficulty keeping their attention on driving 
and auto's allow them to be even less attentive. My Hemi Challenger is my 
nostalgia car and I like the 6 speed manual tranny.
comments.author: 1redrubberball

comments.text:
Sir i'm almost 14 now and i live in north carolina. automatic's are gay as 
f--k i have been able to drive a manual since i was 11 so i don't know 
where you live but not all american's like auto's.but they are great for 
older people .
comments.author: Nick Moore

comments.text:
+1redrubberball yeah im from usa and i could care less what people think of 
us but thats the running joke on how dangerous drivers we are. Its really a 
lost art when i was in school id say 70-80% couldn't drive manual.
comments.author: BOONDOCK SAINT

comments.text:
+BOONDOCK SAINT
I don't have any difficulty driving my 6 speed manual Hemi Challenger and 
eating a burger and handling the tranny.
Manual trannys were much more common 3-4 decades and further back, than 
today, in America. However, for full throttle runs, no manual transmission 
is going to throw a shift faster than a good automatic with most drivers.
comments.author: 1redrubberball

comments.text:
+AGH0STBUSTER5 yeah but a pain in the ass for traffic which is 90% of what 
Americans drive in. plus how can we chomp down on mcdonalds if we don't 
have a free hand :) I use to despise cars like prius and toyota because I 
was a muscle fan but for practicality I understand why you would buy one.
comments.author: BOONDOCK SAINT

comments.text:
+JohnnyWhiplash1 Me too, but as a whole, autos are more common in the US 
than manuals. In Europe, autos are rare. They're becoming more common there 
too. Don't let AGH0STBUSTERS fool you. Of course the car guys in Europe are 
gonna dog us for having autos, but Euro commuters use them too. As for your 
comment AGH0STBUSTERS, car guys in the US prefer manuals unless their focus 
is bracket racing. This Mustang is a drag car. If it was a road racer or 
autocross it would have a manual. And if you don't understand why we care 
about straight line speed, I'll just refer you to 9:40 in the video. That 
explains it all.
comments.author: Brad B

comments.text: I am an American and I absolutely DESPISE automatic transmissions.
comments.author: JohnnyWhiplash1

comments.text:
+AGH0STBUSTER5
Additionally, they keep you involved in the mechanics of driving in a way 
that autos can't.
Just mind and machine.
comments.author: 1redrubberball

comments.text:
Manuals allow you to use almost all of an engines power, they're cheaper to 
buy and maintain than autos, they get better gas millage albeit marginal 
and they help your brakes last longer
comments.author: AGH0STBUSTER5

comments.text:
Because it isn't required of us, I think if everyone had to drive one for 
their test, they'd be more popular. Autos are also more accessible, anyone 
can get in and drive it without worrying too much. Plus its super fast to 
shift with a ratchet, you couldn't match that time with a manual yourself. 
There are exceptions, but joe schmoe cant.
comments.author: BCH37501

comments.text:
Because few can ever throw a shift with a manual, as fast as a good 
automatic. Ronnie Sox was legendary for being able to do it.
comments.author: 1redrubberball

comments.author: davess357

comments.text:
+davess357 The Ford 9 inch rearend is virtually bullet proof. It has been 
and still is the preferred choice in most high  powered race cars like 
NASCAR and NHRA. The weak links are the axles, u joints and drive shafts.

comments.text:

have sticky slicks. Those 9" rear ends did break.

comments.text: Big muscle California Drag Stang﻿
comments.author: Michael Ricci

comments.text:
I love Mustangs, but owning a '67 Cougar has kinda ruined 'em for me. I 
know that the Cougar was based off of the Mustang, and not the other way 
around, but I've become so accustomed to my Cougar that Cougars just seem 
like cooler cars, even though that's completely not true. Any other big

comments.text:
Drive's shows are done in rotations. That means, if Big Muscle is on drive 
for the next 13 weeks, Tuned is out until those 13 weeks are up. Chris 
Harris' show is constant all year round, but sometimes Chris and his 
cameraman need to take a break. Don't be upset when your favorite show 
suddenly doesn't show up in your subscription box, there are specific 
reasons why.
comments.author: DZone Motorsport TV

one?
